title: Can we use the word 'even' in academic writing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Why not? Consider the following, hypothetical examples of “academic writing,” brazenly using the word “even.” The king hoped to pay for his new palace by raising taxes, but even his counselors urged him to find an alternative means of paying for the structure, as the population was already restless due to high food prices.Even though the crinoline dress was often singled out, in early feminist literature, as a hallmark of patriarchal society, more recent research by feminist scholars has revealed that the crinoline was actually seen as empowering by women at the time - a practical alternative to previous styles, a way of claiming public space (to the annoyance of many men), and a means of ostentatious, personal display.An even distribution of rations was absolutely impossible, as the food stores laid in prior to the siege Wheeler’s entrenchment at Kanpur were not of a kind that could be easily and practically divided among hundreds of people.In the 1840s and 1850s, even steamships could not match the speed - or the magnificence - of the typical China clipper on the long haul between London or New York and Nanjing.For a long time, it was believed that it might even have been possible for the explorers to reach the fabled falls, but the recent discovery of their remains, so far off course, strongly suggests that they became lost, and never reached their destination.

If for some reason you think it will put a hex on your descendants to the 9th generation if you use that word in academic writing, you could always substitute the phrase “divisible by 2.” If you’re writing an article about number theory, at least.
